docs.lead_paragraph: Faced with sluggish sales tax revenues and soaring pension, health insurance and Medicaid costs, counties in the New York metropolitan region are facing cuts in popular services and hikes in local taxes to balance their budgets. And Albany isn't helping. On Long Island, the Nassau County executive, Thomas Suozzi, confronts a fiscal double whammy. Not only must he surmount the current economic downturn, but he must do so even as he grapples with the financial crisis left behind by his Republican predecessor, Thomas Gulotta. Mr. Suozzi's 2003 budget proposal shows him moving aggressively to balance the books and overhaul creaky government operations. For example, his plan contemplates shrinking the county payroll by 1,400 workers -- a reduction of about 15 percent over the next 12 months. It also includes the 19.4 percent increase in the county portion of the property tax bill, which the Legislature's Democratic majority approved last spring. He has warned that future tax increases may be necessary if the economy does not rebound, mandated costs continue to rise or unions refuse givebacks.

docs.lead_paragraph: The state's largest health care union has reached a tentative agreement with a company that employs 2,800 home health aides for higher wages and better benefits. It is the second such contract that the union, 1199/S.E.I.U., has negotiated in three weeks. The company, Patient Care Inc., agreed on Thursday to a 16-month contract that includes a pay increase and that, for the first time, gives workers health benefits, overtime pay and paid time off, the union announced yesterday. The workers will get a base wage of $6.55 an hour, union officials said, up from the $6 or less an hour many of the employees have been paid.

Wendt, the former General Electric executive who was hailed as a savior when he was hired to run Conseco, announced yesterday that he was stepping down as chief executive of the troubled financial services company. He said he would stay on as chairman, however. Conseco did not name a new chief executive, but said that William J. Shea, the president and chief operating officer, would be in charge of the company's negotiations with creditors to restructure its $6 billion in debt.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of homeowners in Texas are expected to lose their insurance coverage in the next year while others are seeing huge increases in premiums in a crisis that could harm the state's economy. It has already become a central issue in the governors' race. Experts say the situation in Texas is the most extreme in the nation, at a time when homeowners' insurance has become harder to attain and more costly in every state, with insurers saying it is a marginally profitable part of the business at best. As a whole, the insurance industry is in a difficult period, as companies have suffered huge losses from the stock market collapse and from the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: Texas Home Insurance Crisis Roils Residents and Top Race

docs.abstract: Texas has highest average premiums for homeowners' insurance in nation; crisis could harm state's economy and has already become central issue in governors' race; experts say insurance industry as whole is in difficult period, but problems in Texas derive mostly from unique circumstances there: Texas is magnet for bad weather, and state's regulatory structure has managed to hurt both insurers and consumers; on Sept 24, Farmers Insurance, second biggest insurer in Texas, announced plans to end coverage for 700,000 homeowner customers; State Farm, state's leading insurer, has stopped selling new homeowner policies in Texas and several other states because of losses; two companies account for more than 50 percent of Texas homeowner insurance market; situation is disrupting real estate market, as potential home buyers say they are unable to secure homeowners insurance; insurers note that unlike 49 other states, Texas has its own state-written standards that require them to provide far broader coverage than is required elsewhere; Tony Sanchez, Gov Rick Perry's Democratic challenger, has criticized Perry for accepting campaign contributions from insurance companies and blamed his administration for allowing premiums to rise; photo; map; chart (L)

Carl McCall did not summon so much as a note of his customary preacherly inflection yesterday, and his jokes were halfhearted as he unveiled his state budget reform plan at a breakfast forum at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in Manhattan. It was a sharp contrast to the cocksure jubilation that Mr. McCall, the state comptroller and Democratic candidate for governor, displayed Thursday night in the same hotel, when he had a crowd of Democratic supporters, including Al Gore, chanting, ''It's time for Carl McCall.''
